page.title: 03Farming:hops at Cradley Hall
page.content: Cradley Hall farm is run by Mr.Price who also manages other farms. He grows hops as his main crop and keeps 150 beef cattle that are bought in makets in Dorset. Mr. Price owns most of his machinary including specialized hop equipment. The income from the hops is very variable; he is already negotiating a price for the 1988 crop. Mr Price has a problem with the unsteady prices of hops. Last year he did not sell some hops because the price was low (Â£100). This was due to competition from other countries. He hopes to change a yard of Goldings, used for lager, to Challenger, used for beer. Most of his hops are taditional english Fuggles. It costs about Â£5000 per hectare to replant or reestablish a hop yard and then one must wait 3 years for the first harvest.
